author: jgm
content: I don't have a problem with block proposers outsourcing block building if they want to, and there's nothing that could be done to prevent that anyway.  But forcing block proposers to include a given execution payload goes, for me at least, against the grain of what a decentralized network is tying to achieve (note there is no definition of "winning" so I cannot be certain this is the intention, but it certainly suggests it).

author: pmcgoohan
content: Not if the payload is the product of consensus- then it is fully decentralized. Block proposers acting on their own are perfectly centralized, just as they would be if they got to decide account balances etc on their own.

author: jgm
content:
Although block producers are (by definition) individually centralized that doesn't matter, as far as I can see, as they only individually have 1/250000 of the network under their control.  So for censorship they could decide to censor a given transaction but that would have minimal impact on the network overall as their chance to be able to censor for _n_ blocks goes to 0 pretty quickly.

As for payload being the product of consensus: this comes back to my "sledgehammer to crack a nut" comment earlier.  The economic incentives for validators require no more than self-interest for them to work (assuming the no more than 1/3 are corrupted with perverse incentives in some way).  MEV, in most of its forms, is ultimately just one or another way of profiting from existing inefficiencies and as long as those inefficiencies remain I don't see MEV disappearing,  Having a consensus mechanism for what goes in to a block, when the only efficient answer is already "what pays most", seems like significant overkill.  What would it enable/prevent?

For example, if a tx with max base fee _x_ entered the ordered queue of transactions (or broad equivalent) and at the point the tx was due to be added to a block the base fee was higher than _x_ it wouldn't be included, and would remain unincluded for an unbounded amount of time.

author: jgm
content:
I think we either have strict ordering of some sort, which is complicated and slow and comes with its own set of attacks, or we accept that there's no single unequivocally fair way to do this and let market forces and decentralization be the push and pull that finds an equilibrium (with the potential for having some sort of "proof of fair selection" for block proposers if required due to the equilibrium moving too far towards a long-term centralized result).

My opinion is that any strict ordering system is going to be very hard to build, although I'd be very happy to take a look at any proposed system.  And anything less than a strict ordering system is going to be open to abuse enough such that it wouldn't look too different from the free-for-all that nominally exists today.  But again, happy to take a look at anything that could provide a workable solution.

(Another opinion is that I think that the requirements on the chain today will look very different from the requirements on the chain in a few years' time, and so worry about anything that builds for the current requirements and places an undue burden on a chain whose primary role would be to secure data roots and proofs on a periodic basis.)

I think in general the idea/direction of Ethereum so far to move somewhat to a separation of concerns to prevent ending up with too high of a requirements for running validators (which is centralizing). PBS is a like this, but so is DAS+sharding.
As I understand it, you want every validator to see, verify, and store every transaction they see, and include that logic ("should be in block within N seconds") in the fork choice rule?

author: pmcgoohan
content: That's a good point and needs thought. Certainly geth full nodes see all pending txs at the moment, but im aware that sharding is  moving away from this. Seems again there is a general eth2 consensus tradeoff here about how hands-off validators can safely be.

author: pietjepuk
content:
Yes, there's also movements the opposite direction though. Or rather, making sure validators do the work we want them to do themselves instead of relying on some centralized party at no cost to themselves (i.e. no loss of privacy/slashability). [0]
As far as making block composition more fair and/or including it in fork choice/consensus, it'd make sense to make sure that it's not cheatable by lazy validators that just defer that "delay check" to some centralized party (to get around e.g. bandwidth and latency requirements that come with listening to all tx activity yourself).

[0] https://dankradfeist.de/ethereum/2021/09/30/proofs-of-custody.html

EDIT: Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but as far as I know it is (barring any to-be-added penalties) in the validator's best interest to vote for a wrongly ordered block (i.e. better than letting the slot end up empty). That will net a validator the most rewards. But _proving_ whether someone saw or didn't see a transaction in a certain time window is challenging (if not outright impossible).

author: jgm
content: Yeah it's proving that an entity did or did not see a given transaction that is, as far as I'm aware, tricky to achieve (I haven't looked at the various DAG-based solutions for transaction ordering for a while, but they all used to have some sort of ultimate system to resolve conflicts and decide on a canonical ordering so wouldn't work for our needs, even ignoring the gas issue).

author: jgm
content:
The problem with a 90% fair system is that the remaining 10% can be exploited, and given that there is money to be made then it's likely that the 10% will utilize whatever holes exist in the system.

In my opinion the best bet against censorship is to give each block proposer autonomy, as we'll only hit censorship problems if all of the proposers are corrupt (reduce all to whatever value you want for censorship duration,but given that we already assume that at least 2/3 of the network is not corrupt, or at least self-interested enough to do what is best for themselves, it seems that isn't an issue).
